questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought into the intensive care unit for septic shock due to malaria. He is currently on mechanical ventilation via an endotracheal tube, and is sedated on propofol. Medications administered include chloroquine, heparin, and propofol. Which of the following is true regarding the volume of distribution (VD) and lipophilicity of these medications?

choices.text: Chloroquine has a low VD since it is hydrophobic
Heparin has a low VD since it is hydrophobic
Heparin has a high VD since it is hydrophilic
Propofol has a low VD since it is lipophilic
Propofol has a high VD since it is lipophilic

questions.solution:
Lipophilicity affects the volume of distribution of medications. The more hydrophobic (lipophilic) a medication, the more easily it can diffuse through the lipid bilayer of cell membranes and distribute throughout the body, especially in adipose tissue. Medications that are very hydrophobic (lipophilic) tend to have high volumes of distribution. For example, propofol is very lipophilic and its volume of distribution can approach 60 L/kg in adults. This explains why propranolol, unlike many other beta-blockers, can be used to treat essential tremor and performance anxiety – it is much more lipophilic than other beta-blockers and easily diffuses across the blood-brain barrier.  

On the other hand, medications that are very hydrophilic (lipophobic) tend to stay in the bloodstream, as they do not readily cross cell membranes. For example, heparin’s volume of distribution is around 0.1 L/kg in adults.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chloroquine has a low VD since it is hydrophobic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Chloroquine is actually very hydrophobic (lipophilic) and thus has a very high VD.
❌ Heparin has a low VD since it is hydrophobic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Heparin is actually very hydrophilic (lipophobic) and thus has a low VD.
❌ Heparin has a high VD since it is hydrophilic:
Incorrect: Medications with a high VD  are generally hydrophobic (lipophilic), since hydrophobic molecules can easily cross lipid membrane layers and distribute widely throughout tissue. Heparin is actually very hydrophilic (lipophobic) and thus has a low VD.
❌ Propofol has a low VD since it is lipophilic:
Incorrect: Medications with a low VD  are generally hydrophilic (lipophobic), since hydrophilic molecules tend to stay in the bloodstream and not distribute widely. Propofol is actually very hydrophobic (lipophilic) and thus has a very high VD.
✅ Propofol has a high VD since it is lipophilic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of pharmacists compares inhaled anesthetic agents in a series of experiments. The graph below shows a comparison between agents A and B. The x-axis represents the blood-gas partition coefficient, and the y-axis represents the minimum alveolar concentration (MAC). Which of the following best describes the property of anesthetic agent A when compared to agent B?

choices.text: Greater decrease in cerebral blood flow

questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the alveolar concentration of an inhaled anesthetic that prevents movement in 50% of patients responding to a noxious stimulus, such as a surgical incision. An anesthetic’s potency is inversely correlated with its MAC. This relationship is represented mathematically as potency = 1/MAC. MAC is influenced by several factors, including the following:
 
  •  Age – MAC decreases as the patient gets older 
  •  Pregnancy – MAC decreases during pregnancy 
  •  Temperature – MAC decreases as body temperature falls 
  •  Other drugs – MAC decreases if the patient is receiving opioids, other anesthetics, or psychotropic  agents 

Option Analysis

✅ Higher potency:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Faster induction:
Incorrect: Anesthetic agents with a high blood-gas partition coefficient have greater solubility in the blood. If an agent has a high coefficient, then a more significant amount of the anesthetic will need to be absorbed by the blood before being passed on to the brain's fatty tissue. As a result, these anesthetics will have a slower induction time.  
❌ Faster equilibration with the brain:
Incorrect: The uptake of an anesthetic depends upon its solubility in the blood. If an agent is highly soluble in blood, then a greater amount of the anesthetic remains in the blood, resulting in delayed saturation of the brain. As a result, it will take longer for the concentration of agent A in the bloodstream to equilibrate with that in the brain.  
❌ Lower blood solubility:
Incorrect: Anesthetic A has a high blood-alveolar coefficient, which is a measure of the solubility of an  inhaled anesthetic in blood. Therefore, agent A has higher blood solubility when compared to agent B.  
❌ Greater decrease in cerebral blood flow:
Incorrect: Inhaled anesthetics, apart from nitrous oxide, increase cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressures. Nitric oxide has a blood-gas partition coefficient of 0.47, whereas agent A has a coefficient exceeding 100. As a result, it is unlikely that agent A is nitric oxide.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate right shoulder pain. The patient was standing on a ladder painting the exterior wall of his house. He lost balance and subsequently fell onto his right shoulder. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 147/82 mmHg, and pulse is 105/min. Plain radiography reveals a dislocated right shoulder. A closed reduction under an intravenous anesthetic agent is performed. A single bolus of propofol is administered, which provides adequate sedation for the procedure. This medication increases the patient’s risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic that can cause vasodilation and cardiovascular depression, resulting in hypotension.

Common parenteral anesthetics (e.g., thiopental, midazolam, propofol, etomidate) have similar properties and mechanisms of action. They work by either stimulating GABA receptors or increasing their sensitivity to GABA molecules. These anesthetics have rapid onset (20-30 seconds) and a short duration of action. They are commonly used for induction of anesthesia and maintenance in short procedures such as tracheal intubation.

Ketamine, on the other hand, blocks NMDA receptors. Ketamine also has a rapid onset but a longer duration of action.

The side effects of different intravenous anesthetics and their mechanisms of action are summarized below:  

Option Analysis

❌ Bronchoconstriction:
Incorrect: Thiopental is an intravenous anesthetic that can cause mast cells in the airways to release histamine and result in bronchoconstriction. As a result, the medication is not typically administered to patients with a history of asthma.  
❌ Anterograde amnesia:
Incorrect: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine with a slower onset than the other intravenous anesthetics. The medication can lead to anterograde amnesia, unable to form new memories.  
❌ Adrenal suppression:
Incorrect: Etomidate is a common parenteral anesthetic that potentiates the effect of GABAA. It can cause adrenal suppression but is unlikely to cause cardiovascular depression. It is preferred for patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, cerebral vascular disease, or hypovolemia since they are at greater risk for hypotension and its associated complications.  
✅ Cardiovascular depression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Methemoglobinemia:
Incorrect: Select agents (e.g., lidocaine, prilocaine, benzocaine) can cause methemoglobinemia, especially in infants younger than 12 months of age with additional risk factors (e.g., G6PD deficiency, concurrent administration of other methemoglobin-inducing medication). However, propofol is not associated with methemoglobinemia.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old is undergoing anesthetic induction for a coronary artery bypass operation. The patient is given inhaled anesthetic gas, intubated, sedated with propofol, and placed on the ventilator. While the surgeon is preparing for thoracotomy, the anesthesia team initiates placement of a triple lumen catheter in the right internal jugular vein. The patient receives an injection of bupivacaine between the heads of the sternocleidomastoid for analgesia, and needle aspiration is performed under ultrasound guidance to confirm placement in the internal jugular vein. During cannulation, the patient is noted to become progressively cyanotic. The patient's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 132/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 84% on 100% FIO2. Physical examination demonstrates pale, gray skin, lips, and nail beds. Cardiopulmonary exam demonstrates bilateral breath sounds and normal S1, S2 without murmurs, rubs or gallops. A stat electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus tachycardia and an image of the patient's blood gas sample is demonstrated below.   Which of the following best describes the most likely precipitant of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Oxidation of iron in heme from Ferrous (Fe2+) to ferric (Fe3+) state
Thromboembolism originating in the deep femoral vein
Inhibition of voltage gated Na+ channels and cardiac conduction blockade
Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air spaces
Mediastinal shift and impairment of venous outflow

questions.solution:
This patient rapidly develops cyanosis, tachycardia, and hypoxemia despite adequate ventilation. An arterial blood gas sample demonstrates the classic chocolate colored blood, indicative of methemoglobinemia, a known side effect of local anesthetics.   

Local anesthetics, while generally safe, do carry a range of side effects that carry significant morbidity and mortality. These medications are commonly used for nerve blocks, minor skin procedures, or prior to placement of indwelling catheters due to their ability to reversibly block voltage gated sodium channels, thereby impeding conduction in pain fibers.  

Side effects of local anesthetics include both central nervous system and cardiovascular toxicity. In particular, the medication bupivacaine is well known for inducing CNS depression at low doses and CNS excitotoxicity such as tremor, convulsions or seizures at higher doses. The cardiovascular side effect profile results from the ability of local anesthetics to bind fast Na+ channels in cardiac myocytes--resulting in reduction of cardiac contractility and arrhythmia generation. The one exception to this cardiac side effect profile is cocaine, which actually stimulates myocytes and increases contractility. Lastly, all local anesthetics (especially benzocaine) are known to induce methemoglobinemia when injected or applied topically. Exposure to the anesthetic agent results in the oxidation of iron found in heme from the ferrous (Fe2+) to the ferric (Fe3+) state. The ferric form of heme cannot bind oxygen, resulting in profound cyanosis, and an inability to oxygenate despite adequate ventilation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Oxidation of iron in heme from Ferrous (Fe2+) to ferric (Fe3+) state:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thromboembolism originating in the deep femoral vein:
Incorrect: A massive pulmonary embolism presents with hypotension, tachycardia and failure to oxygenate despite adequate ventilation. This patient is without unilateral lower extremity swelling making this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, the change in color of blood to chocolate brown is indicative of methemoglobinemia.   
❌ Inhibition of voltage gated Na+ channels and cardiac conduction blockade:
Incorrect: Local anesthetics have been known to induce cardiac arrhythmias via fast sodium channel blockade and induction of subsequent cardiac arrhythmia. This patient’s telemetry strip demonstrates sinus tachycardia.    
❌ Leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air spaces:
Incorrect: ARDS or acute respiratory distress syndrome is characterized by leakage of protein-rich fluid into the alveolar air space. This disease is characterized by bilateral, interstitial, non-cardiogenic edema following an acute insult and a PaO2/FIO2 <300.  
❌ Mediastinal shift and impairment of venous outflow:
Incorrect: A tension pneumothorax can result in mediastinal shift and subsequent impairment of venous outflow. Tension pneumothorax presents with diminished breath sounds, jugular venous distension, hypotension, hypoxia, and tachycardia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is undergoing an evaluation for respiratory distress in the emergency department. Following initial assessment, the patient’s oxygen saturation declines 76% on 6L nasal cannula. There is an associated decline in mental status. The emergency medicine physician proceeds to intubate the patient using a medication that works by preventing acetylcholine from binding to receptors on the motor end plate, thus inhibiting depolarization. Which of the following medications was most likely administered to achieve these effects?
questions.solution:
This patient undergoes rapid sequence intubation using a medication that works via competitive inhibition of the acetylcholine receptor, thus preventing depolarization. Of the medications listed, only rocuronium, a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, functions in this manner.    

Neuromuscular blockers are divided into two categories: depolarizing agents and non-depolarizing agents. Depolarizing agents include medications such as succinylcholine, which are strong acetylcholine receptor agonists. By strongly binding to the acetylcholine receptor, these medications result in a prolonged depolarization, thereby preventing subsequent depolarizations and muscle contractions.    

In contrast, non-depolarizing agents such as atracurium, cisatracurium, pancuronium, rocuronium, tubocurarine, and vecuronium are strong acetylcholine receptor antagonists. These medications block acetylcholine from binding its receptor, thus preventing depolarization altogether.   

Option Analysis

✅ Rocuronium :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Succinylcholine :
Incorrect: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that works via acetylcholine receptor agonism.   
❌ Propofol :
Incorrect: Propofol is an intravenous anesthetic used for sedation, not neuromuscular blockade. Administration of propofol with etomidate can produce deep sedation, but will not relax the vocal cords for adequate passage of an endotracheal tube.  
❌ Ketamine :
Incorrect: Ketamine works via NMDA receptor antagonism and not via competitive acetylcholine receptor antagonism.  
❌ Midazolam:
Incorrect: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that works by facilitating GABAA channel opening.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to worsening dyspnea and wheezing. The patient has had a chronic productive cough for the past several years, which has worsened in the past 2 weeks. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 102/84 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Physical examination reveals accessory muscle use during respiration. The patient frequently coughs and produces significant quantities of yellowish sputum. Diffuse wheezes are heard bilaterally on chest auscultation. The patient is started on antibiotics and supplemental oxygen. Despite appropriate treatment, he passes away several days later in the intensive care unit, and an autopsy is performed. Which of the following will most likely be seen on histopathological evaluation of this patient’s lungs?

choices.text: Increased thickness of submucosal mucinous glands
Numerous crystalloids made of eosinophil proteins
Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells
Nodules with concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers

questions.solution:
This patient has dyspnea, productive cough, and wheezing in the setting of a long smoking history, which raises concern for underlying chronic bronchitis. The fever, tachycardia, and reduced oxygen saturation are suspicious for a superimposed pneumonia. Autopsy of this patient’s lungs will reveal bronchial mucinous gland hyperplasia and hypertrophy.  

Chronic bronchitis (CB) describes inflammation of the tracheobronchial tree that leads to increased mucus production. The most important cause is cigarette smoking, which irritates the airway mucosa, leading to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucinous glands in the main bronchi and goblet cells in the bronchioles. Symptoms include productive cough due to excess mucous secretion and wheezing due to airway narrowing.  

The diagnosis of CB is made on clinical grounds; it is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. In post-mortem scenarios, the diagnosis can be made via the Reid index, which measures the ratio of the thickness of the bronchial mucinous gland layer relative to the total thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the glands. Normally, the ratio is less than 0.3, but for patients with CB it can exceed 0.4.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased thickness of submucosal mucinous glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diffuse panlobular emphysema :
Incorrect: Diffuse panacinar (panlobular) emphysema is classically seen in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, in which alveolar proteases are uninhibited, resulting in destruction of the alveolar parenchyma. In contrast, this patient has chronic bronchitis, which makes another histopathological finding more likely. 
❌ Numerous crystalloids made of eosinophil proteins:
Incorrect: Charcot-Leyden crystals are crystalloids formed from the breakdown of eosinophils. These crystals are seen in patients with asthma. In contrast, this patient has chronic bronchitis, which makes another histopathological finding more likely. 
❌ Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells:
Incorrect: Noncaseating granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis. This patient, who suffers from chronic bronchitis, would have a different finding on histopathological examination of the bronchial wall. 
❌ Nodules with concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers:
Incorrect: Silicotic nodules demonstrate concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center. This “whorled” appearance of collagen fibers is characteristic of silicosis. However, this patient lacks risk factors (e.g. history of working in mining or glass manufacturing) that would predispose him to developing silicosis.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of shortness of breath over the past few months. She has had no fever or weight loss over this time period. The patient drinks 2-3 glasses of wine on the weekends and does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. She states her father died of liver disease at the age of 55. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a prolonged expiratory phase and scattered wheezes bilaterally. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the costal margin. There is no palmar erythema, spider angiomata, or ascites noted. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Leukocytes   7,000/mm3 
 Creatinine   0.7 mg/dL 
 Total bilirubin   1.0 mg/dL 
 Glucose  92 mg/dL 
 AST  78 U/L 
 ALT  81 U/L 
Which of the following changes will most likely be observed on histopathological examination of this patient’s proximal and distal acini?
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath despite no prior smoking history, hepatomegaly, and elevated liver enzymes. She likely has alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency, which is characterized by impaired hepatic secretion of AAT. The condition results in emphysema, due to increased elastase activity and subsequent breakdown of lung tissue, as well as liver injury.  

Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls. The alveoli become progressively weaker, lose their ability to stretch and recoil, and eventually collapse, resulting in air trapping.  

Emphysema can be further classified based on which alveoli clusters (termed acini) are damaged. The three types of emphysema are:  

 1) Centriacinar emphysema is the most common type and involves damages to the central alveoli of the acinus. This is the pattern seen with cigarette smoking and typically affects the upper lobes of the lungs.  
2) Panacinar emphysema affects the entire acinus and usually occurs in the lower lobes. This pattern is associated with AAT deficiency.  
3) Paraseptal emphysema is characterized by enlargement of the distal alveoli of the acinus. This type typically affects lung tissue on the periphery of the lobules, near the interlobular septa.



Option Analysis

❌   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Enlargement  Normal :
Incorrect: Enlargement of the proximal acini with distal sparing is seen in centriacinar (centrilobular) emphysema. This type of emphysema is classically seen in patients who smoke cigarettes. In contrast, this patient has no history of tobacco use, making centriacinar emphysema unlikely. 
✅   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Enlargement  Enlargement :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Normal Enlargement :
Incorrect: Enlargement of distal acini with proximal sparing is seen in distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema. The condition can be a cause for spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults. However, this patient has shortness of breath, elevated liver enzymes, and no smoking history, which raises concerns for alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. AAT deficiency typically presents with panacinar emphysema.
❌   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Normal Normal :
Incorrect: This patient likely has alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. Normal acini are not seen in patients with this condition, as the absence of AAT leads to increased elastase activity and increased breakdown of the lung parenchyma.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to acute-onset shortness of breath and wheezing. The patient has no smoking history and works as an accountant. Despite aggressive medical intervention, the patient passes away in the hospital due to respiratory failure. Autopsy examination is performed, and sputum analysis reveals numerous crystalloids composed of eosinophil proteins; one is shown below:  


 Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Further histopathological examination is also likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Spiral-shaped desquamated epithelium on sputum analysis
Nodules surrounded by whorls of concentric collagen fibers on lung biopsy
Elastase-mediated alveolar septal destruction on lung biopsy
Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells on lymph node biopsy
Dust-laden macrophages with dense collagen deposition on lung biopsy

questions.solution:
This patient presented with shortness of breath and has Charcot-Leyden crystals on sputum analysis. He likely had respiratory failure secondary to an acute asthma exacerbation.     

Charcot-Leyden crystals can be found in patients with asthma. These crystals are hexagonal, double-pointed, and formed from the breakdown of eosinophils.    

Patients with asthma may also have Curschmann spirals, which are mucous plugs containing whorls of shed epithelial cells. These plugs can be dangerous, as they can not only block air exchange but can also prevent inhaled medications from reaching the site of inflammation.  


Image reproduced from Wikipedia



Option Analysis

✅ Spiral-shaped desquamated epithelium on sputum analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nodules surrounded by whorls of concentric collagen fibers on lung biopsy:
Incorrect: Silicotic nodules demonstrate concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center. This “whorled” appearance of collagen fibers is characteristic of silicosis. However, this patient lacks risk factors (e.g. history of working in mining or glass manufacturing) that would place him at risk of developing silicosis.
❌ Elastase-mediated alveolar septal destruction on lung biopsy:
Incorrect: Emphysema causes destruction of alveolar parenchyma due to increased neutrophil-elastase activity. However, this patient’s sputum analysis reveals Charcot-Leyden crystals. This patient most likely has an underlying diagnosis of asthma, as opposed to emphysema.
❌ Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells on lymph node biopsy:
Incorrect: This histopathological finding is classically seen in sarcoidosis. However, this patient’s sputum analysis reveals Charcot-Leyden crystals. This patient most likely has an underlying diagnosis of asthma, as opposed to sarcoidosis.
❌ Dust-laden macrophages with dense collagen deposition on lung biopsy:
Incorrect: This finding may be seen in patients with coal workers pneumoconiosis. However, this patient has no history of being exposed to large quantities of coal dust that would place him at risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of progressive exertional dyspnea. He states he has had worsening shortness of breath when walking down the block to the grocery store. He does not have a productive cough. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. He has a 42-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a thin male with an increased anterior-posterior chest diameter. Lung auscultation reveals scattered wheezes bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals normal S1 and S2. Neck veins are nondistended. Which of the following additional findings is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Reversal of dyspnea with albuterol administration

questions.solution:
This patient has dyspnea, wheezing, and increased anterior-posterior chest diameter in the setting of a long smoking history. He most likely has emphysema.

Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls. The alveoli become progressively weaker, lose their ability to stretch and recoil, and eventually collapse, resulting in air trapping.  

To mitigate this symptom, patients learn to expire slowly with pursed lips, which raises airway pressure and prevents airway collapse. The classic emphysematous patient is described as a “pink puffer,” since in the early stages of the disease, the alveoli are still able to participate in gas exchange, and cyanosis is absent. Additionally, due to air-trapping and hyperinflation of the lungs, individuals tend to develop a barrel-shaped chest.   

In contrast, patients with chronic bronchitis are classically described as “blue bloaters”. This is because obstruction of airflow can get so severe that deoxygenated blood from the right heart reaches the left heart without participating in adequate gas exchange. As a result, patients with chronic bronchitis can appear cyanotic.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Pursed-lip breathing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Clubbing of digits:
Incorrect: Clubbing of the digits is not typically seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), even in patients with associated hypoxemia. If digital clubbing is present, it raises concerns for comorbidities such as lung cancer, interstitial lung disease, or bronchiectasis.
❌ Hepatomegaly:
Incorrect: Hepatomegaly can be seen in patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. The condition causes liver injury and emphysema, due to increased elastase activity and lung tissue breakdown. AAT deficiency typically manifests in individuals between 40 to 50-years-old who have little or no smoking history. In contrast, this patient is more than 60-years-old and has a long smoking history, making another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Reversal of dyspnea with albuterol administration:
Incorrect: Dyspnea that improves with albuterol administration is characteristic of asthma, which is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction. In contrast, this patient has persistent shortness of breath, wheezing, and a long smoking history, which is concerning for emphysema. Symptoms of emphysema would not improve with albuterol administration.
❌ Peripheral edema:
Incorrect: Over time, pulmonary hypertension puts strain on the right heart and can lead to right heart failure (RHF), also termed cor pulmonale. RHF typically manifests with jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, S3 heart sound, and hepatomegaly due to congestion. This patient’s non-distended neck veins and normal heart sounds make RHF unlikely.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male comes to the clinic due to a productive cough. The patient has had a purulent, productive cough for the past few years and has recently noticed bloody streaks in his sputum. He has a history of recurrent sinus infections that improve with antibiotic treatment. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit substances. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezes and crackles. Cardiovascular examination shows a cardiac point of maximal impulse that is palpated at the right 5th intercostal space. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a productive cough in the setting of recurrent sinus infections and situs inversus, as indicated by the point of maximal impulse being located in the right chest. These findings are suggestive of bronchiectasis secondary to primary ciliary dyskinesia (also termed Kartagener syndrome).  

In healthy individuals, coordinated movement of the cilia is necessary for removal of overlying mucus and pathogens. Therefore, the mucociliary escalator is the primary defense mechanism of the airways. In patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia, an autosomal recessive mutation results in dysmotile cilia. These patients have impaired clearance of mucus and pathogens, which leads to chronic sinopulmonary symptoms. Recurrent infections cause permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles due to destruction of smooth muscle and supporting elastic tissue, resulting in bronchiectasis.   

Bronchiectasis presents clinically as a persistent cough that produces copious amounts of purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Pulmonary function testing will reveal findings consistent with obstructive pulmonary disease secondary to air trapping.  



Option Analysis

❌ Episodes of bronchial hyperreactivity :
Incorrect: Asthma can cause a persistent and chronic cough in patients. However, this patient’s recurrent pulmonary infections and situs inversus (presence of cardiac point of maximal impulse in the right chest) are more suggestive of a different diagnosis. 
✅ Ciliary dysfunction :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Abnormal ion conductance:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis is caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, which encodes for a transmembrane chloride channel. Although this patient is presenting with recurrent pulmonary infections and a chronic, persistent cough, the finding of situs inversus makes another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Protease-mediated destruction of alveolar walls:
Incorrect: Emphysema secondary to alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency can result in dyspnea and a chronic, persistent cough. However, patients also typically present with signs of hepatic dysfunction (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis). This patient’s situs inversus makes another diagnosis more likely. 
❌ Widespread formation of noncaseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis can result in a chronic, nonproductive cough. However, it would not account for the patient’s situs inversus.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the clinic for evaluation of a worsening productive cough. The symptoms have been worsening over the past week, and she has noticed increased production of foul-smelling, blood-tinged sputum. She has had multiple similar episodes in the past that mildly improved with antibiotics, but the cough has always persisted. The patient does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit substances. She takes pancreatic enzyme supplements for chronic diarrhea. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing. Lung auscultation demonstrates diffuse wheezes and crackles. Which of the following findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Barrel chest with flattening of hemidiaphragms
Irregular thickening of the interlobular septa with honeycombing
Pleural thickening with multiple nodular pleural lesions
Dilated bronchi and bronchioles with signet-ring sign
Hilar lymphadenopathy with bilateral reticular opacities

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a productive cough in the setting of recurrent pulmonary infections and chronic diarrhea. She likely has bronchiectasis secondary to cystic fibrosis (CF).  

Patients with CF have thickened, viscous, and inspissated secretions at various mucosal surfaces, leading to lung injury, gastrointestinal malfunction, and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency. In the lungs, the abnormal secretions accumulate and predispose patients to superimposed infections. Recurrent infections cause permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles due to destruction of smooth muscle and the supporting elastic tissue, resulting in bronchiectasis.   

Bronchiectasis presents clinically as a persistent cough that produces copious amounts of purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Diagnosis can be made via CT scan, which will show dilated bronchi and bronchioles. The "signet-ring" sign is a classic imaging feature of bronchiectasis. It describes the cross-sectional appearance of a dilated, air-filled bronchus that is contiguous with a branch of the pulmonary artery (the jewel on the ring). Pulmonary function testing in patients with bronchiectasis will reveal findings consistent with obstructive pulmonary disease due to air trapping.  



Option Analysis

❌ Barrel chest with flattening of hemidiaphragms:
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with emphysema. Emphysema is characterized by chronic air-trapping that results in an increased anteroposterior chest diameter, bilateral hyperlucency, and flattening of the hemidiaphragms. However, patients with emphysema do not typically present with increased sputum production.
❌ Irregular thickening of the interlobular septa with honeycombing:
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a condition that causes irreversible fibrosis. Patients with IPF may also present with a chronic cough. However, this patient’s underlying cystic fibrosis would predispose her to another pulmonary condition.
❌ Pleural thickening with multiple nodular pleural lesions:
Incorrect: Chronic exposure to asbestos can result in asbestosis and potentially mesothelioma, which is characterized by pleural thickening. 
✅ Dilated bronchi and bronchioles with signet-ring sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hilar lymphadenopathy with bilateral reticular opacities:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disorder characterized by non-caseating granulomatous inflammation that typically presents initially with dyspnea and a dry cough. However, this patient’s underlying cystic fibrosis would predispose her to another pulmonary condition.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent due to acute-onset wheezing and shortness of breath. The patient was visiting her neighbor, who recently got a pet kitten, when she suddenly started feeling short of breath. Past medical history is significant for asthma, and she has normally found relief after using an albuterol inhaler. However, the inhaler has been ineffective during the current episode. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals accessory muscle use while breathing. Diffuse expiratory wheezes are heard bilaterally on chest auscultation. The patient is re-evaluated in 10 minutes. Which of the following findings, if present on repeat examination, is most concerning for impending respiratory failure?

choices.text: Drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration

questions.solution:
Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways that causes recurrent episodes of wheezing, dyspnea, chest tightness, and cough. Asthma typically presents as an episodic disorder caused by inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of the bronchial smooth muscle, leading to reversible bronchoconstriction. Although the specific causes of asthma are ultimately unknown, it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors (e.g., air pollution, cigarette smoke, allergens).  

An asthma attack is characterized by severe dyspnea and wheezing due to bronchoconstriction and mucus plugging, which leads to trapping of air in distal airways with progressive hyperinflation of the lungs. Most cases of asthma exacerbations can be treated with bronchodilators (e.g. albuterol) and glucocorticoids. In rare cases, patients with attacks refractory to treatment may show signs of impending respiratory failure such as absence of breath sounds due to respiratory fatigue, inappropriately low respiratory rate, and depressed mental status (lethargy or agitation) due to increasing partial pressure of carbon dioxide. These patients require immediate intubation and ventilatory support.  



Option Analysis

✅ Absent wheezing :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tachypnea:
Incorrect: Tachypnea is a common finding in patients with mild to severe asthma exacerbations. In contrast, decreasing respiratory rate is suggestive of imminent respiratory arrest due to respiratory muscle fatigue. 
❌ Wheezing throughout expiration and inspiration:
Incorrect: Asthma exacerbations occur due to widespread bronchoconstriction. Narrowing of the airway lumen can cause wheezing, which is more commonly heard on expiration. Inspiratory and expiratory wheezing is suggestive of a severe asthma exacerbation. However, another clinical finding is more suggestive of imminent respiratory arrest.
❌ Accessory muscle use:
Incorrect: The use of respiratory accessory muscles is usually seen in moderate and severe cases of asthma exacerbations. However, another clinical finding is more suggestive of imminent respiratory arrest.
❌ Drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration :
Incorrect: Pulsus paradoxus may be seen in cases of severe asthma; this is caused by a drop in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration, which leads to pooling of blood in the pulmonary vasculature, decrease in left ventricular preload, and subsequent drop in blood pressure. In contrast, it is the absence of pulsus paradoxus that is concerning for impending respiratory failure secondary to respiratory muscle fatigue.

questions.text: A team of scientists are examining the pathophysiology of extrinsic asthma. They observe in a group of rats that initial exposure to an allergen elicits production of an immunoglobulin. The immunoglobulins then attach to the Fc receptors located on Cell X, an immune cell identified by the researchers. On subsequent exposure to the same allergen, the allergen binds to the immunoglobulins on Cell X and induces cross-linking, resulting in immediate bronchospasm, mucus production, and eventual recruitment of additional immune cells. Which of the following cells was likely identified by the researchers as Cell X?
questions.solution:
Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of the bronchial smooth muscle. The condition arises due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors (e.g., air pollution, cigarette smoke, allergens), which predisposes patients with asthma to type I hypersensitivity reactions.   

Asthma begins when a trigger (e.g. allergen) causes excessive activation of type 2 helper T cells (Th2 cells) and prompts them to produce cytokines (IL-4, IL-13). These cytokines stimulate plasma cells to produce IgE antibodies, which then coat the surface of mast cells. On reexposure to the allergen, the IgEs cross-link, and the mast cells release intracellular granules containing histamines, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins. Mast cell-derived inflammatory mediators produce two waves of reaction, an early-phase and a late-phase:  

- The early-phase reaction is characterized by bronchoconstriction, mucus production, and edema, leading to airway obstruction.  
- The late-phase reaction is mainly inflammatory and is characterized by recruitment of leukocytes (eosinophils, basophils, lymphocytes) to the reaction site. These leukocytes release additional inflammatory mediators, such as major basic protein, which causes epithelial damage.  

Initially, these inflammatory changes are reversible. However, over time, irreversible changes take place. These include scarring and fibrosis of the airways, as well as smooth muscle hypertrophy and hyperplasia, which ultimately result in airway narrowing.



Option Analysis

✅ Mast cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Eosinophils:
Incorrect: Eosinophils play an integral role in the pathophysiology of asthma and are involved in the late-phase reaction. Leukocytes (e.g., neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils) are recruited by mast cell-derived mediators from the early-phase reaction. Cell X, as shown in the experiment, is involved in the early-phase reaction and is therefore unlikely to be an eosinophil. 
❌ Basophils:
Incorrect: Mast cell-derived mediators from the early-phase reaction cause recruitment of leukocytes (e.g., neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils). Cell X, as shown in the experiment, is involved in the early-phase reaction and is therefore unlikely to be a basophil. 
❌ Plasma cells:
Incorrect: The researchers noted that after allergen exposure, there was production of a specific immunoglobulin (IgE) that bound to Fc receptors on Cell X. The IgE immunoglobulins are synthesized and secreted by plasma cells. However, cross-linking of immunoglobulins found on the surface of plasma cells would not precipitate an acute asthma attack. Therefore, Cell X is unlikely to be a plasma cell. 
❌ Th2 cells:
Incorrect: Type 2 T-helper (Th2) cells are involved in the pathogenesis of asthma. These cells produce various cytokines such as interleukin (IL)-4, IL-5, IL-13, and GM-CSF. Th2 cells are involved in stimulating IgE-producing plasma cells and recruiting eosinophils. However, IgE antibodies would not bind to the surface of Th2 Cells and subsequently cross-link to induce asthma. Therefore, Cell X is unlikely to be a Th2 cell.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic due to shortness of breath. The patient’s symptoms began around a year ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has no history of tobacco or illicit substance use. Spirometry is performed and a flow-volume loop is obtained. The patient’s flow-volume loop is shown below on the right (normal is depicted by the flow-volume loop on the left).  

 
 
 Images reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following will most likely be discovered on further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: History of cirrhosis in the absence of alcohol intake
Obese individual with chronic fatigue and hypersomnolence
Ptosis and diplopia that improves with edrophonium administration

questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath, no smoking history, and a flow-volume loop showing an obstructive lung pattern, which raises concerns for alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. AAT is an enzyme that normally protects the body from elastase. In AAT deficiency, there is impaired hepatic secretion of AAT, which results in emphysema (due to increased breakdown of lung tissue) and liver cirrhosis (due to AAT accumulation within the liver)  

A flow-volume loop can be obtained as part of the work-up process. The graph plots inspiratory and expiratory flow (on the Y-axis) against volume (on the X-axis) while the patient performs maximally forced inspiratory and expiratory maneuvers. The upper-half of the loop (above the X-axis) shows the expiratory effort of the patient, whereas the lower-half of the loop (below the X-axis) shows the inspiratory effort of the patient.  

This patient’s flow-volume loop demonstrates a concave or "scooped-out" appearance that is classically seen in obstructive lung diseases (e.g., asthma, emphysema). Physiologically, the concave pattern seen on expiration occurs due to loss of airway support secondary to destruction of the surrounding lung parenchyma, which causes premature airway closure and air-trapping.  

Option Analysis

✅ History of cirrhosis in the absence of alcohol intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amiodarone intake:
Incorrect: Amiodarone can cause pulmonary fibrosis. This side-effect occurs due to the medication’s toxic effects on pulmonary cells, which results in cell death and fibrosis. This patient’s flow-volume loop suggests an obstructive lung condition, as opposed to the restrictive lung disease pattern seen in patients with pulmonary fibrosis. 
❌ Occupational exposure to asbestos:
Incorrect: Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by chronic inhalation of asbestos fibers. Chronic asbestos exposure results in pulmonary fibrosis, which instead causes a restrictive lung disease pattern to be seen on spirometry. 
❌ Obese individual with chronic fatigue and hypersomnolence :
Incorrect: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome is a form of restrictive lung disease caused by a mechanical limitation of the chest wall to expand to full capacity. However, this patient’s flow-volume loop is suggestive of an obstructive lung condition.
❌ Ptosis and diplopia that improves with edrophonium administration:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that results in a restrictive lung disease due to weakness of the inspiratory muscles. This prevents the chest cavity from expanding to its largest potential size. However, this patient’s flow-volume loop is more consistent with that of an obstructive lung condition.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to her outpatient provider due to recurrent episodes of dyspnea and wheezing over the past several months. These episodes last around 30 minutes and spontaneously resolve. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient’s uncle passed away from cystic fibrosis at a young age. In the office, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is resting comfortably. Physical examination reveals scattered wheezes on chest auscultation. Cardiac and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following is the next best step in diagnosing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Spirometry before and after bronchodilator administration
Sweat chloride test after pilocarpine administration

questions.solution:
This patient has intermittent episodes of shortness of breath that spontaneously resolve. She likely has asthma, which can be diagnosed by performing spirometry before and after bronchodilation administration.  

Asthma is an episodic disorder caused by inflammation and hyperresponsiveness of the bronchial smooth muscle, which leads to reversible bronchoconstriction. Patients develop symptoms in childhood and may present with cough, wheezing, dyspnea, and chest tightness.  

Clinical suspicion for asthma should arise if a patient has symptoms that vary in intensity and severity over time. In addition, two characteristics need to be demonstrated in order to diagnose asthma, which are: 1) evidence of airway obstruction, and 2) reversibility in the degree of obstruction.    

Spirometry is the first-line diagnostic test. During an asthma attack, spirometry will demonstrate results consistent with obstructive lung disease, such as a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. The reversibility of the airflow obstruction can be tested by administering a short-acting bronchodilator (e.g. albuterol) and repeating the spirometry. Reversibility is defined as a 12% or greater increase in FEV1 after bronchodilator administration.   

Option Analysis

✅ Spirometry before and after bronchodilator administration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sweat chloride test after pilocarpine administration:
Incorrect: A sweat chloride test can be used to diagnose cystic fibrosis in patients with respiratory complaints. These patients may also present with frequent foul-smelling stools, recurrent pneumonia, and failure to thrive. However, none of these other symptoms are present in this patient. 
❌ Skin allergy testing:
Incorrect: Although certain allergens such as pet dander, molds, or dust mites can trigger asthma in children, skin allergy testing is not necessary for the diagnosis of asthma. Instead, skin allergen testing can be used as an ancillary test to identify triggers and develop strategies to avoid them.
❌ Chest radiograph after bronchodilator administration :
Incorrect: Chest imaging can be performed if initial testing with spirometry is inconclusive. A chest radiograph can be used to evaluate for structural causes (e.g. vascular ring) that may lead to wheezing.
❌ Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) measurement :
Incorrect: Patients with asthma typically have elevated IgE levels. However, measurement of serum IgE levels is not needed to diagnose a patient with the condition.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine evaluation. He has had a chronic productive cough for the past 5 years, with occasional dyspnea and wheezing. He smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 40 years, but stopped several months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral diffuse crackles and rales on chest auscultation. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is performed, which confirms the diagnosis of chronic bronchitis-predominant chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Which of the following PFT findings are most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  ↑   ↑
Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓ ↑
Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓↓

questions.solution:
Chronic bronchitis (CB) is diagnosed on clinical grounds. It is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. Signs and symptoms of CB include productive cough (due to excess mucus secretion) and wheezing (due to airway narrowing).  

CB is characterized by inflammation of the tracheobronchial tree, which leads to increased mucus production. The most important cause is cigarette smoking, which irritates the mucosa of the airways, leading to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucinous glands in the main bronchi and goblet cells in the bronchioles. This histological change increases mucus production, causing airway obstruction.   

The subsequent air-trapping causes an increase in total lung capacity. However, in contrast with emphysema, where there is destruction of pulmonary parenchyma, alveolar tissue is relatively intact in CB. Therefore, patients with CB-predominant COPD typically have a normal diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO). In contrast, patients with emphysema-predominant COPD have a reduced DLCO.  



Option Analysis

✅   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  Normal  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  ↑   ↑ :
Incorrect: In patients with asthma, there is increased total lung capacity. The DLCO is either normal or elevated, depending on the severity of the asthma exacerbation. One potential explanation for the elevated DLCO is that increases in negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration draws blood into the thorax. This leads to improved ventilation-perfusion matching secondary to increased perfusion of the lung apices.
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: Patients with emphysema typically have increased total lung capacity due to air trapping and decreased DLCO since alveolar destruction decreases the surface area for gaseous exchange. However, this patient has a chronic bronchitis-predominant pattern of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity ↓↓:
Incorrect: Patients with interstitial lung disease typically have decreased total lung capacity due to irreversible fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. The fibrosis also contributes to poor diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (CO) across the alveolar wall. 
❌   Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO)  Total lung capacity  Normal  Normal:
Incorrect: This patient with chronic bronchitis-predominant COPD would not have normal lung function on testing.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and productive cough for the past year. The patient has not seen a physician in several years. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a thin woman who breathes through pursed-lip. Lung auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing bilaterally. Which of the following parameters is most likely to be increased in this patient?

choices.text: Forced expiratory volume in one second

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has shortness of breath and pursed-lip breathing in the setting of an extensive smoking history. She most likely has emphysema.

Emphysema is one of the obstructive lung diseases, which are a group of conditions characterized by obstruction of airflow and air trapping within the lungs. The underlying cause of air trapping varies based on etiology. Asthma, for example, causes air trapping due to bronchoconstriction, whereas emphysema causes air trapping due to destruction of alveolar and bronchial tissue.  

 Lung function testing in patients with obstructive lung diseases typically shows a small reduction in forced vital capacity (FVC) and significant reduction in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) because these individuals have narrow airways, which hinder how fast air can leave the lungs. Thus, the FEV1/FVC ratio is also reduced.  

Moreover, in this patient with emphysema, there is protease-mediated damage of the extracellular matrix. The loss of elastic tissue causes a two-fold impact. First, there is an increase in lung compliance (change in volume per unit change in pressure). Second, there is increased air trapping, since the loss of elastic tissue surrounding the respiratory bronchioles causes their collapse during expiration.  


Option Analysis

✅ Lung compliance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Forced vital capacity:
Incorrect: Forced vital capacity (FVC) measures the amount of air a person can breathe out forcefully after taking as deep a breath as possible. This parameter is typically decreased in patients with obstructive lung diseases due to impaired elastic recoil of the lungs. 
❌ Forced expiratory volume in one second:
Incorrect: Patients with obstructive lung diseases have a significant reduction in forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), which measures the total amount of air that can be forcibly exhaled in the first second of the FVC test.
❌ Lung elastic recoil:
Incorrect: Lung elastic recoil is typically decreased in COPD as a result of destruction of elastic tissue.
❌ Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide:
Incorrect: Diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is decreased in patients with emphysema, because alveolar destruction decreases the surface area for gaseous exchange.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parent due to sudden-onset shortness of breath and wheezing. The patient has been taking aspirin for several days due to a sprained ankle. On review of systems, she endorses a persistent sensation of nasal congestion over the past several months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals a girl in moderate distress. Nasal examination reveals bilateral, gray, glistening mucoid masses. The loss of which of the following mediators after aspirin ingestion is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath and wheezing in the setting of aspirin use and bilateral nasal polyps. She most likely has aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).  

AERD is caused by abnormalities in the arachidonic acid biosynthesis pathway. Arachidonic acid can be metabolized via two different pathways: the 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO) pathway and the cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) pathway. The 5-LO pathway produces leukotrienes from arachidonic acid (e.g., leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4), whereas the COX-1 pathway produces prostacyclins, prostaglandins, and thromboxanes from arachidonic acid. Normally, COX-1 pathway products counterbalance the effects of leukotrienes. Most notably, prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) has potent bronchodilatory properties and can inhibit eosinophils and mast cells, thereby preventing leukotriene release.  

Patients with AERD have an underlying defect resulting in constitutive overproduction of leukotrienes and concomitant underproduction of COX-1 pathway products. When these patients take aspirin or an NSAID, there is further COX-1 inhibition and leukotriene overproduction. Patients classically present with asthma, chronic/recurrent rhinosinusitis, and nasal polyps, which can manifest with nasal congestion and reduced olfactory sensation.  



Option Analysis

✅ PGE2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ PGI2:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin I2 (PGI2) is synthesized from arachidonic acid by the enzyme COX-1. PGI2 is involved in vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation. It is not, however, involved in suppressing the production of leukotrienes. 
❌ PGF2:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin F2 (PGF2) is synthesized from arachidonic acid by the enzyme COX-1. PGF2 is involved in smooth muscle contraction. It is not, however, involved in suppressing production of leukotrienes.
❌ TXA2:
Incorrect: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is involved in vasodilation and promotes platelet aggregation. It is not, however, involved in suppressing production of leukotrienes.
❌ PGH2:
Incorrect: Prostaglandin H2 (PGH2) is synthesized from arachidonic acid by the enzyme COX-1. It is not, however, involved in suppressing production of leukotrienes.
